attributes.title: Liberty vs. Safety: A Survey Experiment on Attitudes Toward Coronavirus Policy Responses

q1.value: Liberty vs. Safety: A Survey Experiment on Attitudes Toward Coronavirus Policy Responses

q2.value: Kevin Cope, Adam Chilton, Mila Versteeg, Charles Crabtree

q3.value: How much liberty are people willing to trade for perceived safety? During the height of the coronavirus outbreak, we assess experimentally how people on two continents balance civil liberties against possible increased protection from the virus. We further explore whether information that proposed actions violate the constitution changes peoples’ willingness to trade liberty for lives.

q4.value:
1. A larger number of reported lives-saved increases support for policies.
2. Policies that are particularly draconian and pose a heavy burden on society receive lower levels of support.
3. Knowledge that policies might violate the constitution changes the level of support for these policies.
4. Certain types of respondents are more willing to tolerate infringements on their liberties than others (for example, people that are particularly worried about their own health, the elderly, people with certain political views).
5. The correlation between reported number of lives saved and policy support will be larger for respondents at higher risk of contracting and dying from the virus (i.e., older respondents, those more concerned about it).
6. People in countries with more libertarian traditions (e.g., the United States) are less willing to support liberty-restricting policies (such as forced conscription and limitations on speech) than respondents in countries with more statist or communitarian traditions (Japan, China, Taiwan, and South Korea). Similarly, people in those latter countries are more willing to support public-provision-restricting policies (such as school closings).
7. Policies that distribute their burden more narrowly (e.g., affecting only the sick) will receive more support, and policies that mainly affect non-citizens will receive the greatest support

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Respondents are presented with a brief history of the coronavirus outbreak and how governments have enacted a range of measures in response. Respondents are told that their government is considering one of nine policy interventions to combat it, and that public-health officials project each of the policies to reduce infections by some number, thereby saving some related number of lives. Half of respondents are also told that legal experts have concluded that the policies are constitutionally problematic. 

Each proposed policy is then presented one at a time. Each of the nine policies varies in the right or liberty it burdens how that burden is distributed, total burden level. Each policy is paired with one of four randomly selected numbers of infections which the proposed policy would avert, and a corresponding number of lives that would be saved as a result. Respondents are then asked to indicate their support on a four-point scale, from strongly oppose implementing to strongly support implementing.

q9.value: Each respondent will be randomly assigned to one of two constitutional treatments. For each respondent, each policy will be randomly assigned one of three infections-averted/lives-saved treatments.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: The data are being collected and are not yet available to the researchers.

question.value: Participants will be recruited from a nationally representative pool of U.S. adults assembled by the survey firm Lucid. Participants are paid less than $2 their participation.

q13.value: The sample size is 3,000 U.S. adults.

q14.value: The number is chosen to ensure that our study is adequately powered and to maximize the external validity of our findings.

question.value:
We manipulate a constitutional treatment: with half of respondents receiving a control (no statement) and half being told that "Before continuing, it is worth noting that many legal experts believe that each of these policies may not comply with the [country] Constitution by, for instance, violating basic civil liberties or not providing sufficient due process."

We also manipulate an infections-averted/lives-saved treatment, with the following four values:  

Infections Averted/Lives Saved

3,400–7,000/120–240
51,000–110,000/1,700–3,600
410,000–840,000/14,000–29,000
7.1 million–15 million/240,000–500,000

We measure respondents' support for each policy on a four-point scale, from strongly oppose implementing to strongly support implementing.

We also collect responses to a series of questions about the tradeoff between fighting the coronavirus on one hand, and law, safety, and the economy on the other, and about views toward President Trump.

Our primary analysis is designed to understand the level of support for the nine policy proposals to respond to coronavirus (questions 3 to 11). 

Graphical Evidence: We will begin by simply graphing the support for each question. To do so, we will graph the percent of respondents that support the policy proposals (support will be all respondents that said they either strongly or somewhat support the proposal). We will report the mean and 90 percent confidence interval for all nine proposals. 

We will then break out the responses to each of these questions in three further ways: (1) by treatment 1 (information on constitutionality); (b) by treatment 2; and (3) by treatments 1 and 2 at the same time (e.g. there will be eight groups for each question). For each of the cuts at the data, again we will report the mean and 90 percent confidence intervals. 

Regressions: In addition to graphically exploring our results, we will estimate the average treatment effect of our treatments on our outcomes for the eight treatment groups (four different virus-impact treatments and two constitutional treatments). To do so, we will estimate OLS regressions. Our outcome measures will be the extent to which respondents support the individual policy proposals and an index that pool the answers to all nine questions for each respondent. Our primary specifications will use the full response scale. We will include an indicator variable for each treatment (both treatment 1 and 2) and each question in the pooled outcome. We will include a set of mean-centered pre-treatment demographic covariates to increase the precision of our estimates. We will cluster standard errors at the level of treatment, the respondent. When testing the equality of our treatments on our outcomes, we will conduct Wald tests. We will report p-values and declare statistical significance for p-values less than 0.05.

We will look at conditional responses by looking at both the aggregate level of support for each of the policies (and by treatment group) for based on the following groups: (1) political views (support for Trump, support for Trump’s handling of the coronavirus crisis, and political affiliation); (2) level of attentiveness to the news; (3) education levels; and (4) age groups. We will conduct these tests by examining the results using our primary regression specifications, and by interacting these variables with the treatments. 

We will also report the aggrege responses to each of the six post-treatment questions on attitudes to fighting the crisis (questions 12 to 17). In addition to reporting to these for the overall pool of respondents, we will report these results based on whether people received the constitution treatment.

q1.value: Effects of a short PMR exercise on state vitality

q2.value: Yanick Jack Tobler, Alan-David Mardi , Chantal Vogt

q3.value: For the course "Experimentalpsychologisches Praktikum" we are conducting an online intervention and measure its effects on vitality. The participants will be divided into a "PMR group" that will follow an instructed 12 minute relaxation exercise and a "Focus on breathing group" which will be instructed to pay attention to their breathing and act as a control group.

q4.value:
A 12-minute online PMR intervention will lead to a significant drop in vitality. 
Vitality is significantly lower in the intervention group "PMR" than in the control group "Focus on breathing".

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: After recruitment, participants will be randomly assigned to either the PMR exercise or to the "Focus on breathing" condition. Vitality will be measure in both groups prior to and after the intervention. Randomized controlled trial

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects will be recruited with flyers in public places, ads in social media groups and blogs, student contact and student mailing lists. The population is not limited to students but can be expected to mostly contain students from universities in Zurich, Switzerland. 
Inclusion criterias are 18 years of age and no psychological disorders. Reason to exclude participants are missing data, early termination of the experiment and failing to meet inclusion criterias.
Participants will have the chance to win a coupon for Migros and psychology students are eligible to earn 0.5 participation hours (Versuchspersonenstunden).

q13.value: We aim to recruit 250 participants but will work with the number we are able to recruit up till data collection.

q14.value: Project leader instructed us to aim for about 250 participants.

question.value: We aim to manipulate vitality by either administering a 12 minute PMR exercise or a 12 minute task which will instruct participants to "focus on breathing"

We assess demographics of the participants including age, gender, education and occupation.
We measure vitality with the german adaptation of the "Subjective Vitality Scale SVS-G" before and after completing the intervention or control task.
We plan to use the ANOVA model including t-tests for our analysis of the data.

q23.value: We will not work with missing or imcomplete data.

attributes.title: Auswirkungen einer kurzen Entspannungsübung auf Stress und Wohlbefinden

q1.value: Auswirkungen einer kurzen Entspannungsübung auf Stress und Wohlbefinden

q2.value: Milan Rusmir, Eleonora Martinelli, Julia Baur, Judith Breuer

q4.value:
Hypothese 1: 
Das Selbstwertgefühl von Studenten wird durch eine kurzfristige PMR-Übung erhöht.
Hypothese 2: 
PMR erhöht das Selbstwertgefühl von Studenten effektiver als eine Atemübung.
Hypothese 3:
Die Effektivität der Verbesserung des Selbstwertgefühls durch die progressive
Muskelentspannung ist unabhängig davon, ob die Studierenden im 2. oder 4. Semester 
sind.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Querschnittstudie
Between subject - Design, 
Einfaktoriell (Entspannungsübung), zwei Bedingungen (PMR oder Atemübung)
Univariat (Selbstwertgefühl)
Randomisierte Zuteilung auf Versuchsbedingung

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Die Versuchspersonen werden durch die sozialen Medien, Fyler oder den persönlichen Kontakt rekrutiert. Sie können entweder an der Verlosung eines Migros-Gutscheines teilnehmen oder alternativ als Psychologiestudent/in eine halbe Versuchspersonenstunde erhalten. Versuchspersonen müssen mindestens 18 Jahre alt sein und an einer Universität studieren. Des Weiteren sollten sie keine psychischen Erkrankungen aufweisen.

q13.value: Das Ziel für die Untersuchung ist es ca. 200 Versuchspersonen zu rekrutieren. Wir werden versuchen, ca. 230 Studenten/innen zu rekurtieren, da wir annehmen, dass nicht alle die Studie vollständig terminieren werden.

question.value:
Die abhängige Variable setzt sich aus dem subjektiven Stressempfinden nach der zugeteilten Entspannungsübung und dem individuell wahrgenommenen Selbstwertgefühl zusammen. 
Das Stressempfinden wird anhand des "Perceived Stress Questionnaires (PSQ20) – Deutsche Fassung" gemessen. Das Selbstwertgefühl hingegen anhand der "Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale (RSES)".
Für die Analyse werden wir einen t-Test für unabhängige Stichproben verwenden .

registration_responses.q2: Milan Rusmir, Eleonora Martinelli, Julia Baur, Judith Breuer

Hypothese 2:

Hypothese 3:
Die Effektivität der Verbesserung des Selbstwertgefühls durch die progressive
Muskelentspannung ist unabhängig davon, ob die Studierenden im 2. oder 4. Semester 
sind.

Querschnittstudie
Between subject - Design, 
Einfaktoriell (Entspannungsübung), zwei Bedingungen (PMR oder Atemübung)
Univariat (Selbstwertgefühl)
Randomisierte Zuteilung auf Versuchsbedingung
registration_responses.q12.question: Die Versuchspersonen werden durch die sozialen Medien, Fyler oder den persönlichen Kontakt rekrutiert. Sie können entweder an der Verlosung eines Migros-Gutscheines teilnehmen oder alternativ als Psychologiestudent/in eine halbe Versuchspersonenstunde erhalten. Versuchspersonen müssen mindestens 18 Jahre alt sein und an einer Universität studieren. Des Weiteren sollten sie keine psychischen Erkrankungen aufweisen.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Die abhängige Variable setzt sich aus dem subjektiven Stressempfinden nach der zugeteilten Entspannungsübung und dem individuell wahrgenommenen Selbstwertgefühl zusammen. 
Das Stressempfinden wird anhand des "Perceived Stress Questionnaires (PSQ20) – Deutsche Fassung" gemessen. Das Selbstwertgefühl hingegen anhand der "Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale (RSES)".
registration_responses.q19.question: Für die Analyse werden wir einen t-Test für unabhängige Stichproben verwenden .

attributes.title: A systematic survey of the causal language use in systematic reviews of observational studies: a study protocol

q1.value: A systematic survey of the causal language use in systematic reviews of observational studies: a study protocol

q3.value:
Authors, often at the behest of the journals to which they are submitting, avoid using causal language when addressing evidence from observational studies. This is true even when the issue of interest is the causal effect of an intervention or exposure. Clarity of thinking and appropriateness of inferences may be enhanced through use of language that reflects the issue under consideration. The objectives of this study are to systematically evaluate the extent and nature of causal language use in systematic reviews of observational studies.
We will conduct a systematic survey of systematic reviews of observational studies addressing modifiable exposures and their possible impact on patient-important outcomes. We will randomly select 200 reviews published in 2019, stratified in a 1:1 ratio by use and non-use of the GRADE. Teams of two reviewers will independently assess study eligibility and extract data using a standardized data extraction forms, with resolution of disagreement by discussion and, if necessary, by third party adjudication. Through examining the inferences, they make in their papers’ discussion, we will evaluate whether the authors’ intent was to address causation or association. We will summarize the use of causal language in the study title, abstract, study question, and results using descriptive statistics. Finally, we will assess whether the language used use is consistent with the intention of the authors. We will determine if results in reviews that did or did not use GRADE differ.
Our systematic survey will summarize current practices regarding causal language use in systematic reviews of observational studies. This study is important because the use of language conveys the authors’ intent and clarifies the interpretation and limitations of the study results. Our findings may influence language use in constructing study questions, reporting results, and drawing conclusions, and will interest systematic review authors, guideline developers, and journal editors.

q4.value: We hypothesize that reviews are more likely to use causal language if they use GRADE, publish in higher impact journals (Journal of American Medical Association, New England Journal of Medicine, The Lancet, British Medical Journal, Annals of Internal Medicine and Public Library of Science Medicine), evaluate therapeutic clinical interventions, report statistically significant results, focus on cohort studies, have larger sample size, and receive funding from for profit organization.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a systematic survey of published systematic reviews of observational studies

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will search EMBASE, MEDLINE, and  Epistemonikos to identify potentially eligible systematic reviews. Since we are interested in current status of how authors use the causal language of their systematic review, we will include the most recent studies. Therefore, we will limit the search in 2019 and, if we find more eligible reviews than required, we will randomly select reviews from among those eligible (see selection of eligible reviews section). If we do not reach the final sample size (see sample size section), we will include reviews published in 2018, or if necessary 2017. 
Teams of two reviewers will screen reviews for eligibility and extract data independently and in duplicate. Reviewers will resolve disagreement through discussion or, if necessary, through consultation with a third reviewer. To ensure the validity and consistency of the review process, we will conduct calibration exercises for each process until reviewers reach a high level of agreement. We will develop and pilot-test standardized forms for eligibility screening and data extraction, and provide reviewers with corresponding detailed written instructions.
When a review reports more than one eligible paired exposure and outcome of interest comparison, we will select the result reported first in the abstract assuming that reflects the authors’ primary interest.

q13.value: We will select 200 reviews published in 2019, stratified in a 1:1 ratio by use and non-use of the GRADE.

q14.value: The primary purpose of this study is to estimate the proportion of reviews using causal language. We estimate our sample size to achieve a 95% CI estimate around the estimated proportion of reviews using causal language. Assuming 50% of reviews use causal language, a sample size of 200 reviews will allow estimation of the prevalence of the causal language use with acceptable precision (± 7 %). Any proportion larger of smaller than 50% will result in narrower confidence intervals.

question.value: NA

We will collect study characteristics from each eligible systematic review including country of corresponding author, journal, study design of included observational studies (cohort, case-control, cross-sectional, case-cohort), number of included observational studies, number of included participants, modifiable exposure, wording for exposure (e.g., intervention, exposure), primary outcome investigated, point estimate and confidence or certainty interval, source of funding and conflict of interest. 
We will review the discussion for statements that convey the authors’ intent regarding causation and, on this basis, make a decision regarding authors’ intent. We will then examine language use in each of the abstract, introduction, methods, and results, and judge whether the language in each section is consistent with the intent. For papers that use GRADE, we will assess whether the GRADE use is consistent with the intent.

We will conduct a descriptive analysis of all variables. We will provide a summary of the study characteristics including the number of included observational studies, number of participants, type of exposure and outcomes. 
We will calculate the proportion of systematic reviews with intent on causation, and will calculate the proportion of systematic review using causal language in the study title, abstract, study question, and results according to the authors’ intent. We will compare them according to the use and non-use of GRADE with the chi-square tests. 
We will conduct two multivariable logistic regression analyses to examine the association between pre-specified study characteristics and, first, causal intent for all reviews included and, second, causal language use in each section of the article for reviews with causal intent.

Any proportion larger of smaller than 50% will result in narrower confidence intervals.
registration_responses.q8.question: We will conduct a systematic survey of published systematic reviews of observational studies
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will search EMBASE, MEDLINE, and  Epistemonikos to identify potentially eligible systematic reviews. Since we are interested in current status of how authors use the causal language of their systematic review, we will include the most recent studies. Therefore, we will limit the search in 2019 and, if we find more eligible reviews than required, we will randomly select reviews from among those eligible (see selection of eligible reviews section). If we do not reach the final sample size (see sample size section), we will include reviews published in 2018, or if necessary 2017. 
Teams of two reviewers will screen reviews for eligibility and extract data independently and in duplicate. Reviewers will resolve disagreement through discussion or, if necessary, through consultation with a third reviewer. To ensure the validity and consistency of the review process, we will conduct calibration exercises for each process until reviewers reach a high level of agreement. We will develop and pilot-test standardized forms for eligibility screening and data extraction, and provide reviewers with corresponding detailed written instructions.
When a review reports more than one eligible paired exposure and outcome of interest comparison, we will select the result reported first in the abstract assuming that reflects the authors’ primary interest.
registration_responses.q16.question: NA
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will collect study characteristics from each eligible systematic review including country of corresponding author, journal, study design of included observational studies (cohort, case-control, cross-sectional, case-cohort), number of included observational studies, number of included participants, modifiable exposure, wording for exposure (e.g., intervention, exposure), primary outcome investigated, point estimate and confidence or certainty interval, source of funding and conflict of interest. 
We will review the discussion for statements that convey the authors’ intent regarding causation and, on this basis, make a decision regarding authors’ intent. We will then examine language use in each of the abstract, introduction, methods, and results, and judge whether the language in each section is consistent with the intent. For papers that use GRADE, we will assess whether the GRADE use is consistent with the intent.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will conduct a descriptive analysis of all variables. We will provide a summary of the study characteristics including the number of included observational studies, number of participants, type of exposure and outcomes. 
We will calculate the proportion of systematic reviews with intent on causation, and will calculate the proportion of systematic review using causal language in the study title, abstract, study question, and results according to the authors’ intent. We will compare them according to the use and non-use of GRADE with the chi-square tests. 
We will conduct two multivariable logistic regression analyses to examine the association between pre-specified study characteristics and, first, causal intent for all reviews included and, second, causal language use in each section of the article for reviews with causal intent.

q3.value: Anecdotal reports suggest that adults with mild autism experience difficulty listening in background noise, yet this phenomenon has seen little formal investigation. This study seeks to test the performance of autistic adults (and matched neurotypical controls) on a laboratory speech-in-noise task. Several listening conditions will be tested, to yield some preliminary data on which aspects of the task elicit between-groups differences in performance.

q4.value:
H1. The autistic group will exhibit higher threshold SNRs than the control group.
H2. An interaction between group and sound level will be evident, with high sound levels leading to greater between-group differences than low sound levels.
H3. An interaction between group and masker location will be evident, with spatially separated maskers leading to greater between-group differences than co-located maskers.
H4. An interaction between group and masker type will be evident.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-sectional study comparing performance of two groups: autistic adults and matched controls (matched on the basis of age, performance IQ, and audiometric thresholds).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A convenience sample of adult, male, audiometrically normal, native English speakers (aged 18-40) will be recruited via advertisements, message boards, social networks, and word of mouth. All will be compensated for their time and provided reasonable travel expenses. Individuals with hearing loss, otological abnormalities, or excessive ear wax will exit at the screening stage. Autistic adults will be required to have received a formal ASD diagnosis. Neurotypical control participants will progress to the full study if they are sufficiently well-matched with autistic participants on the basis of age, audiometric thresholds, and performance IQ.

q13.value:
Autistic group: n = 20
Neurotypical group: n = 20

q14.value: Sample size for this small pilot study is constrained by available resources.

question.value:
OUTCOME MEASURES
Coordinate Response Measure (CRM) thresholds
Measured in quiet, and also in the presence of five different maskers:
- Spatially separated two-talker at 55 dB SPL
- Spatially separated two-talker at 80 dB SPL
- Co-located two-talker at 55 dB SPL
- Spatially separated babble at 55 dB SPL
- Spatially separated babble at 80 dB SPL

COVARIATES
Age (months)
Pure tone audiometric thresholds
Performance IQ (WASI Block Design and Matrix Reasoning)
Adult Autism Spectrum Quotient score

Thresholds in the 55 dB-SPL CRM-masker conditions will be combined into a difference measure - "spatial release from masking" - by subtracting the threshold obtained in the spatially separated condition from that obtained in the co-located condition.

A combined measure of performance IQ will be created from scores on two WASI subtests: Block Design and Matrix Reasoning

RQs 1, 2, and 4: A three-way mixed ANOVA, with a between-subjects factor of Group and within-subject factors of Masker Level and Masker Type.

RQ 3: A two-way mixed ANOVA, with a between-subjects factor of Group and a within-subject factor of Masker Location.

q21.value:
H1. The autistic group will exhibit higher threshold SNRs than the control group (adjusted alpha = 0.0125, one-tailed)
H2. An interaction between group and sound level will be evident, with the autistic group exhibiting relatively higher thresholds at high sound levels than at low sound levels (adjusted alpha = 0.0125, one-tailed)
H3. An interaction between group and masker location will be evident, with the autistic group exhibiting relatively higher thresholds with spatially separated maskers than with co-located maskers (adjusted alpha = 0.0125, one-tailed)
H4. An interaction between group and masker type will be evident (adjusted alpha = 0.0125, two-tailed)

attributes.title: Mindless math: the failings of fluency

q1.value: Correlating time taken in no-trick and performance in trick versions of item

q2.value: Asher Lawson, Richard P. Larrick, Jack B. Soll

q3.value: This study looks for correlational evidence between the difficulty of the prospective computation in a problem and respondents' likelihood of answering correctly in the trick version of the same problem

q4.value: H1: There will be a significant, negative correlation between the average time taken to answer a no-trick version of a problem correctly and the proportion of correct responses in the trick-version of that problem

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a 2 x 8 between-subjects design. There are 8 different levels of numeric demands and two different versions of each problem (trick vs no-trick). Participants are asked to answer one item. Demographic information is collected.

q9.value: After an attention check, participants are randomly assigned to one of 16 cells using Qualtrics' randomizer and embedded data.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will be posted to Amazon's Mechanical Turk. There will be no requirements other than exclusion of participants who have completed a similar study for the same project before.

q13.value: We will collected N = 800 observations. However, the final N will be smaller, as we only look at the correct answers in the no-trick version of the problems.

question.value: We manipulate numeric demands (8 different levels) and trick vs no-trick (2 levels). Rather than relying on our manipulation to exactly manipulate difficulty, we use average log time taken in an item as the independent variable in our analyses.

Log time taken. 
Proportion of correct answers.

The analysis will be the following:

For each of the 8 numeric demands conditions in the 'no-trick' problem version, we will calculate the average log time taken for participants who answered correctly. 

For each of the 8 numeric demands conditions in the 'trick' problem version, we will calculate the average proportion of correct responses.

We will calculate Pearson's correlation coefficient between these 8 average log time values and 8 average proportion of correct response values. These are paired by the level of numeric demands, not participant. The study is between-subjects.

We will test the 1-tailed hypothesis that Pearson's rho < 0.

q22.value: Participants who answered incorrectly in the no-trick condition will be excluded from the sample.

attributes.title: Sense of Agency on the Dark Side – Influence of different emotional states as dopaminergic equivalents on Intentional Binding

q1.value: Sense of Agency on the Dark Side – Influence of different emotional states as dopaminergic equivalents on Intentional Binding.

q2.value: Anna Render, Hedwig Eisenbarth, Petra Jansen, Matt Oxner

q3.value:
The objective of the study is to understand the relationship between dopamine and the intentional binding effect. Intentional Binding is an implicit measurement based on time perception for sense of agency - the subjective feeling of control over one’s actions. As we will not collect dopamine samples, we will operationalise dopamine release by the induction of two different emotional states, pleasure and sexual arousal. Moreover, we would like to examine the connection between the dark triad personality traits (psychopathy and narcissism), substance use history and intentional binding. Alteration in intentional binding have been found for narcissism and substance use history in both directions, we would therefore like to distinguish between the two subtypes of narcissism and subtypes of drug use to clarify these results. Psychopathy has previously been linked to hyperactive dopamine activity, but it has not been linked to intentional binding yet.
Intentional binding is composed of two components: action binding and outcome binding (also tone binding). Action binding is evaluated as a more informative measure of action-outcome association than outcome binding. Outcome binding might depend more on physical characteristics of the outcome because it is more directly associated with sensorimotor prediction, whereas action binding is rather independent (Christensen, Di Costa, Beck, & Haggard, 2019; Wolpe & Rowe, 2014). One can also examine “composite” binding as the sum of action binding and outcome binding (Moore et al., 2010; Moore & Obhi, 2012). However, the differences between action and outcome binding indicate that both measures are more informative when considered separately (Wolpe & Rowe, 2014). Action Binding captures a specific impairment in action planning or generating an action outcome prediction, rather than in the matching process of predicted and observed outcomes. This means that alterations in Action Binding reflect the deficits in the dopaminergic system involved in action execution (Tanaka & Kawabata, 2019). Intense emotional states or high arousal might influence the dopaminergic activity and impair the preciseness of prediction processes, concluding, we expect sexual arousal to decrease Action Binding whilst not affecting Outcome Binding

q4.value:
1.	Emotional manipulation: We expect sexual arousal to cause a decrease in action binding whereas pleasure causes an increase intentional binding compared to baseline levels. There will be no change in the neutral condition in action binding. 
2.	Personality: Trait anxiety, vulnerable narcissism and substance use will be linked to a decrease in action binding, whereas grandiose narcissism and psychopathy will be associated to an increase in action binding. 
3.	Spontaneous Eye blink rates (EBR): The manipulation of sexual arousal will change the EBR dependent on the baseline (low baseline higher EBR, moderate and high baseline lower EBR). EBR will be increased as action binding increases, whereas EBR will be decreased as action binding decreases. 
4.	Pupil dilation: Pupil dilation will increase more in the sexual arousal condition than in the pleasurable condition compared to baselines and will not change from baseline in the neutral condition. Great increases in pupil dilation will be associated with a decrease in action binding, whereas intermediate increases in pupil dilation will be linked to an increase in action binding. 
5.	HRV and HR: We have no specific hypothesis for the relationship of HRV and HR and action binding. 
6.	Effects for intentional binding as a sum will be analysed exploratory. 
7.  Arousal will physiologically be observable in greater pupil dilation, increase in heart rate and gsr.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have a mixed design, between subject is group with 3 levels (sexual arousal, pleasure and neutral), 2 within factors are (action binding, arousal, pleasure) each with 2 measurements (pre and post) and covariates psychopathy, narcissism subtypes, trait anxiety and substance use history, since gender has not been reported to explain differences in binding, we do not expect any. We will control for Spontaneous Eye Blink Rates (dopamine activity), Pupil Dilation (arousal) and skin conductance (arousal level) Heart Rate (arousal level)). 
Participants will be randomly assigned to the groups (sexual arousal, pleasure and neutral), experimental blocks of intentional binding paradigm will be counterbalanced. Equation of gender will be equal in all groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through flyers at the Victoria University of Wellington. Koha for participation will be movie vouchers. Age range is between 18 and 35 years.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 60 participants. If participants have to be excluded due to technical failures, we will continue recruiting until we have full data sets of 60 participants for analysis.

question.value:
We will manipulate sexual arousal with a scene from the movie love by Gaspar Noe. The scene shows a threesome and lasts about 6.5 min. The scene is accompanied by a guitar intro.
We will manipulate pleasure with a scene from the movie pride and prejudice by Joe Wright. The scene shows the intro scene and the protagonists reunion in a field close to the end (your hands are cold) and lasts about 6.5 min. Both scenes are accompanied by classical music.
The neutral video shows people walking down the street randomly, it does not have a continuous plot and lasts about 6.5 min. 
All three videos have been pretested by 10 participants in an online survey and achieved apppropiate ratings.
All of the videos show social interactions and have a similar length.
arousal and pleasure shall be maintained by inserting images (screenshots) of the the movie clip in between each trial for 500ms. Effects of images on binding have been examined in a former study confirming no differences in binding between two neutral conditions, one showing screenshots of the neutral movie and one not including screenshots.

Dependent variable will be action binding (pre and post comparison), a subcomponent of the Intentional Binding Paradigm, which is a computer-based task for perception of intervals between actions (key presses) and consequences (tones) indicating the subjective feeling of control of the participants. In this task (measuring feeling of control), the participants watch an analogue clock rotating two times. In the second lap, participants have to either press the space key (action) or hear a tone (consequence) in the baseline conditions. In the agency conditions, key presses and tones are combined with a delay of 250ms. After each trial, participants make time estimations about the events (either key press or tones depending on the condition) on the analogue clock. The interval between key press and tone is perceived shorter than it really is if shown in one trial compared to when presented individually.  
Objective physiological measurements (heart rate and gsr (emotional response), pupil dilation (arousal) and spontaneous eye blink rates (non-invasive indicator of dopamine activity)) will be measured constantly while participants complete the intentional binding tasks and watch the film clip. Subjective perception of arousal and pleasure will be reported with the affective grid before and after each of the two intentional binding tasks (4 times in total), to see if arousal and pleasure level has maintained. 
Questionnaires (explicit self-reports) included to measure personality traits and substance use history are PPI-R-40 (Psychopathy), NPI-16 and PNI subscales (narcissism subtypes), STAI-T (trait-anxiety) and a modified version of European School Survey Project on Alcohol and Other Drugs for substance use history. 
Videos used will be a scene of movie Love by Gaspar Noe for sexual arousal, the opening and end scene of the movie pride and prejudice for pleasure and a youtube video of people walking down the street for the neutral condition. Videos will be pre-tested with the affective grid in valence and arousal.

We will use linear mixed models with the dependent variable action binding and factors time, pre arousal (before each binding task), group, Psychopathy, Narcissism types, Trait Anxiety, Substance Use History.
We will use linear mixed models with the dependent variable affective rating and the factors pupil size, heart rate and gsr.
Spontaneous Eye Blink Rates will be used to show dopaminergic activity, dependent on baseline of each individual (baseline predicts if the EBR will be increased or decreased because of u-shaped function) and will be used as an additional factor to explain binding. 
Pupil data collected with a sampling rate of 250hz and will be preprocessed with the gazer package of Geller, Winn, Mahr and Mirman, last edited 2019.  For baseline correction, the first 100ms of each trial will be used. Deblinking will be conducted 100ms forward and backward of each blink. 
GSR will be calculated by subtracting the baseline mean (500ms prior to each trialonset) from the maximum value of each trial. 
Heart Rate will be GSR will be calculated by subtracting the baseline mean (500ms prior to each trialonset) from the mean value of each trial.

Spontaneous Eye Blink Rates will be used to show dopaminergic activity, dependent on baseline of each individual (baseline predicts if the EBR will be increased or decreased because of u-shaped function) and will be used as an additional factor to explain binding. 
Pupil data collected with a sampling rate of 250hz and will be preprocessed with the gazer package of Geller, Winn, Mahr and Mirman, last edited 2019.  For baseline correction, the first 100ms of each trial will be used. Deblinking will be conducted 100ms forward and backward of each blink. 
GSR will be calculated by subtracting the baseline mean (500ms prior to each trialonset) from the maximum value of each trial. 
Heart Rate will be GSR will be calculated by subtracting the baseline mean (500ms prior to each trialonset) from the mean value of each trial.

attributes.title: A systematic review of flap outcomes for patients with thrombophilia

q1.value: A systematic review of flap outcomes for patients with thrombophilia

q2.value: Minh Huynh, Victoria Mckinnon, Pavlo Isak, Emily dunn, Mark mcrae, Matthew Mcrae

q3.value: To examine outcomes of flaps for patients with thrombophilia. There is scarce literature on patients with thrombophilia and whether reconstruction with flaps have a higher risk of failure.

q4.value: The authors believe from their anecdotal experiences that patients with thrombophilia are at higher risk of flap failure.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A qualitative systematic review will be performed. If a meta-analysis is possible after data extraction is completed, due to its non-comparative nature, a meta-analysis of proportion will  be performed. Data will be pooled and assessed for heterogeneity and predictive factors for flap outcomes

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The review will be reported in concordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidance. A literature search will performed using Ovid MEDLINE; EMBASE; and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)  databases by two independent reviewers (MH and SR) from their date of inception.

All full text articles that study flap outcomes for patients with thrombophilia will be included. 

The language of publication will be restricted to English. 

The primary outcome is flap failure. Secondary outcomes are predictive factors of flaps (i.e. patient characteristics, type of thrombophilia), salvage procedures, operative details, follow-up time and complications.

q13.value: Sample size will be determined by number of eligible articles included in the study. As this is a systematic review, sample size cannot be calculated.

question.value: Not applicable, statistical analysis will be performed to adjust for confounding factors

The primary outcome is flap failure. Secondary outcomes are predictive factors of flaps (i.e. patient characteristics, type of thrombophilia), salvage procedures, operative details, follow-up time and complications.

If applicable, a meta-analysis of proportion will be performed. Data will be synthesized via meta-analytic pooling of included studies using a random-effects model. Heterogeneity will be quantified using I2 statistics. Pooled data may be presented in forest plots and publication bias may be assessed using a funnel plot. Uni- and multi-variate regressions may be performed, if applicable.

attributes.title: Transition to Parenthood - Negative Social Exchange on Relationship Satisfaction
Better together? Examining the effect of civic education for local officials and citizens in the Philippines on government responsiveness and citizen engagement

q1.value: Better together? Examining the effect of civic education for local officials and citizens in the Philippines on government responsiveness and citizen engagement

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Using a field experiment in the northern Philippines, we test whether training citizens and officials together is more effective than training citizens alone at increasing political participation on the part of citizens and improving local government performance.

q16.value: Citizen participation, government responsiveness (mandatory and optional), civic knowledge of officials and citizens, citizen compliance

q17.value: We randomly assigned villages in the Philippines to two different training interventions: one in which a group of citizens are trained on local government regulations and budgeting, and another in which they are trained together with local government officials on the same content. Half of the villages in each of eight municipalities were randomly assigned to each condition. Using a survey of officials and citizens, validated with behavioral outcomes observed during village assembly meetings, we test the effect of join training compared to "citizens only" training on six primary outcomes: citizen participation, government adherence to mandatory regulations, government responsiveness through non-mandatory action to solicit or incorporate citizen input, civic knowledge among both citizens and local government officials, and citizen compliance with government-directed activities.

q27.value: Responsible Citizens, Empowered Communities in Solidarity for Social Change (RECITE, Inc.)
